case_name: Manu Bhusan Roy Pradhan v. District Magistrate, Jalpaiguri

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 252 of 1972 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 252 of 1972. Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus. K. Gambhir, for the petitioner  amicus curiae  Gobind Mukhoty and G. S. Chatterjee, for the, respondent.

facts.text: Petition forwarded to court by Superintendent, Dum Dum Central Jail, West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: This petition for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus, by Manu Bhusan Roy Pradhan has been forwarded to this Court by the Superintendent, Dum Dum Central Jail, West Bengal.

facts.text: Detention order passed by District Magistrate, Jalpaiguri on August 21, 1971 under Section 3(2) of Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 to prevent petitioner from acting prejudicial to public order.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the order of detention passed by the District Magistrate, Jalpaiguri, on August 21, 1971 in exercise of the powers companyferred on him by S. 9 read with sub-s.  2  of S. 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 26 of 1971  hereinafter called the Act  with a view to preventing the petitioner from acting in any nianner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order,

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on November 11, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: he was arrested on November 11, 1971.

facts.text: On 16-4-71 at about 20.00 hours petitioner along with others committed murderous assault on Shri Bulo Das Gupta causing severe injuries; Das Gupta died in hospital; people terrorised, public peace disturbed.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds of detention served on the petitioner at the time of his arrest read On 16-4-71 at about 20.00 hours you along with others companymitted a murderous assault on Shri Bulo Das Gupta on the road in front of the office of Mahila Samity, Dhupguri, Police Station Dhupguri, District Jalpaiguri causing severe injuries on his person. Shri Das Gupta subsequently died in hospital. As a result of this murder companymitted by you people of the locality became highly terrorised and the public peace was greatly disturbed.

facts.text: On 19-7-1971 at about 19.30 hours petitioner along with others entered Dhupguri High School and set fire to buildings causing irreparable loss; object to dislocate education system; teachers and people panic-stricken, public peace disturbed.

anchor.surface_text: On 19-7-1971 at about 19.30 hours you along with others forcibly entered into Dhupguri High School, Police Station Dhupguri, District Jalpaiguri and set fire to the school buildings causing irreparable loss to the institution in particular and the people in general. you set fire to the school with the ulterior object of causing dislocation in the present system of education and to companypel the school authorities to close down the same. As a result of the fire set by you, the teachers and the local people became panic-stricken and the public peace was greatly disturbed.

facts.text: Detention order reported to State Government on August 23, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The fact of making the detention order was reported to the State Government on August 23, 1971.

facts.text: State Government approved detention on August 31, 1971 and reported to Central Government same day.

anchor.surface_text: It was approved by the said Government on August 31, 1971 the same day this fact was reported to the Central Government.

facts.text: Case placed before Advisory Board on December 9, 1971; opinion dated January 18, 1972 that sufficient cause for detention.

anchor.surface_text: On December 9, 1971 the case was placed before the, Advisory Board which gave its opinion as per its report dated January 18, 1972 that there was sufficient cause for the petitioners detention.

facts.text: State Government confirmed order on February 1, 1972; reported to Central on February 3, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government companyfirmed this order on February 1, 1972 and this fact was reported to the Central Government on February 3, 1972.

facts.text: Petitioner's representation received by State Government on December 11, 1971; considered on January 14, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners representation was received by the State Government on December 11, 1971. But it was companysidered on January 14, 1972.

facts.text: Delay in considering representation due to influx of refugees, Pakistan aggression, busy officers, increase in detention cases from Naxalites.

anchor.surface_text: In the companynter-affidavit this delay has been explained in these words due to influx of refugees as well as the Pakistan aggression at that time, most of the officers of the Home Department of the State Government were very busy with serious problems which threatened and faced the companyntry at that time, and as such the said representation companyld number be companysidered earlier. Moreover I further state that delay was also caused due to abrupt increase in number of the detention cases during that time as there was spate of anti-social activities by Naxalities and other political extremists in the State.

facts.text: Petitioner is 17 years old, studying in Xth class in Dhupguri High School.

anchor.surface_text: Before us Shri S. K. Gambhir, the learned companynsel appearing as amicus curiae submitted that the petitioner, who is only 17 years old and is studying in the Xth class in Dhupguri High School,

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on August 5, 1971 in connection with six cases; bailed out on November 10, 1971; re-arrested soon thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: was arrested on August 5, 1971 in companynection with six cases. He was bailed out on November 10, 1971 but was re-arrested soon thereafter.

facts.text: Petitioner was absconding when detention order made; arrested November 11, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the State it was companytended that the petitioner was found to be absconding when the detention order was made and that lie was arrested on November 11, 1971.

facts.text: Petitioner is staunch supporter of C.P.I.(ML) party and active member of Action squad.

anchor.surface_text: The detenu-petitioner is a staunch supporter of C.P.I.  ML  party and is active member of the Actionsquad of that party.

facts.text: Counter-affidavit affirmed on August 24, 1972 by Deputy Secretary, Home (Special) Department, Government of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: It is numbere-worthy that in that companynter-affidavit, which was affirmed on August 24, 1972 by the Deputy Secretary, Home  Special  Department ofGovernment of West Bengal,

facts.text: Ground 1 is vague and irrelevant to public order.

anchor.surface_text: It was further submitted that ground number I stated in, the order of detention is vague and has also numberrelevance to the maintenance of public order with the result that the petitioners detention must be held to be bad in law

facts.text: Court finds ground 1 raises only law and order problem, irrelevant to public order.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, ground number 1 which does number mention the names details of the others along with whom the petitioner is alleged to have companymitted the assault, only refers to an assault on an individual named Bulo Das Gupta on April 16, 1971 which prima facie appears to raise only a law and order problem.

facts.text: Ground 2 germane to maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: Ground number 2, however, is quite germane to the problem of maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Detention order invalid because ground 1 irrelevant and likely influenced detaining authority.

anchor.surface_text: But the question arises whether in theabsence of ground number 1 which, in our view, Ts wholly irrelevant, the detaining authority would have felt satisfied on the basis of the solitary ground number 2 alone to make the impugned order.

facts.text: Petitioner released by court on October 4, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was released by us by means of a short order on October 4, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: Where power is vested in a statutory authority to deprive the liberty of a subject on its subjective satisfaction with reference to specified matters, if that satisfaction is stated to be based on a number of grounds or for a variety of reasons, all taken together, and if some out of them are found to be number-existent or irrelevant the very exercise of that power is bad.

concepts.interpretation: Detaining authority's subjective satisfaction must be properly based on all stated grounds; irrelevant ones invalidate if influential

Gambhir, the learned counsel appearing as amicus curiae submitted that the petitioner, who is only 17 years old and is studying in the Xth class in Dhupguri High School, was arrested on August 5, 1971 in connection with six cases. He was bailed out on November 10, 1971 but was re-arrested soon thereafter.

arguments.court_reasoning: Notes omission in counter-affidavit regarding prior bail claims, no reply or explanation provided

arguments.claim: Delay in considering representation justified due to influx of refugees, Pakistan aggression, busy officers, increase in detention cases from Naxalites

anchor.surface_text: In the counter-affidavit this delay has been explained in these words due to influx of refugees as well as the Pakistan aggression at that time, most of the officers of the Home Department of the State Government were very busy with serious problems which threatened and faced the country at that time, and as such the said representation could not be considered earlier.

arguments.claim: Averments in para 7 of counter-affidavit that detenu is staunch supporter of C.P.I.(ML), active in action squad, and activities disturbed public order bring case within S.3(1) and (2) even if not referenced in supplied grounds

anchor.surface_text: It was contended that this averment brings the petitioners case within the purview of S. 3 1  and  2  of the Act even though in the grounds supplied to the detenu there was no reference to his being a staunch supporter of C.P.I.  ML  party and to his being an active member of the Action-squad of that party.

arguments.court_reasoning: Validity judged on supplied grounds to detenu, not additional averments in counter-affidavit

arguments.claim: Ground number 1 only refers to assault on individual which prima facie raises only a law and order problem, not public order

anchor.surface_text: In our view, ground number 1 which does not mention the names details of the others along with whom the petitioner is alleged to have committed the assault, only refers to an assault on an individual named Bulo Das Gupta on April 16, 1971 which prima facie appears to raise only a law and order problem.

arguments.claim: Ground number 2 is quite germane to the problem of maintenance of public order

anchor.surface_text: Ground number 2, however, is quite germane to the problem of maintenance of public order.

arguments.claim: In absence of irrelevant ground 1, detaining authority would not have been satisfied based on solitary ground 2 alone; irrelevant ground vitiates detention

anchor.surface_text: But the question arises whether in the absence of ground number 1 which, in our view, is wholly irrelevant, the detaining authority would have felt satisfied on the basis of the solitary ground number 2 alone to make the impugned order.

arguments.claim: Requirement that grounds must not be vague applies to each ground

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Dr. Ram Krishan Bhardwaj v. The State of Delhi laid down that the requirement that the grounds must not be vague must be satisfied with respect to each of the grounds.

arguments.claim: Subjective satisfaction based on multiple grounds vitiated if some irrelevant or non-existent, as per Dwarka Das Bhatia; court cannot substitute objective standard
Detention order invalid as ground 1 irrelevant and might reasonably have affected subjective satisfaction; only two grounds and exclusion might have impacted decision

holdings.text: Ground number 1 only refers to assault on individual which prima facie raises only a law and order problem, not public order

anchor.surface_text: In our view, ground number 1 which does not mention the names details of the others along with whom the petitioner is alleged to have committed the assault, only refers to an assault on an individual named Bulo Das Gupta on April 16, 1971 which prima facie appears to raise only a law and order problem.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies precedent from Arun Ghosh and Ram Manohar Lohia distinguishing law and order (individual harm without community disturbance) from public order based on degree and potential impact on community life.

holdings.text: Ground number 2 is quite germane to the problem of maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: Ground number 2, however, is quite germane to the problem of maintenance of public order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of public order test to facts of school arson causing panic, dislocation of education, and disturbance to teachers and public.

holdings.text: In absence of irrelevant ground 1, detaining authority would not have been satisfied based on solitary ground 2 alone; irrelevant ground vitiates detention

anchor.surface_text: But the question arises whether in the absence of ground number 1 which, in our view, is wholly irrelevant, the detaining authority would have felt satisfied on the basis of the solitary ground number 2 alone to make the impugned order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Poses and answers test of severability; since only two grounds, cannot assume irrelevant one did not contribute to subjective satisfaction.

holdings.text: Requirement that grounds must not be vague applies to each ground

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Dr. Ram Krishan Bhardwaj v. The State of Delhi laid down that the requirement that the grounds must not be vague must be satisfied with respect to each of the grounds.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedent requiring non-vagueness per ground; applied to ground 1 lacking details of accomplices, weapons, injuries, motive.

holdings.text: Subjective satisfaction based on multiple grounds vitiated if some irrelevant or non-existent, as per Dwarka Das Bhatia; court cannot substitute objective standard
holdings.reasoning_summary: Quotes and applies Dwarka Das Bhatia principle: irrelevant grounds invalidate if not shown to be severable without affecting satisfaction.

holdings.text: Detention order invalid as ground 1 irrelevant and might reasonably have affected subjective satisfaction; only two grounds and exclusion might have impacted decision
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Bhatia and Motilal Jain tests to facts: with merely two grounds, irrelevant one (April incident) reasonably influenced decision, vitiating order.

precedents.case_name: Arun Ghosh v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between maintenance of law and order and public order; solitary acts against individuals do not necessarily disturb public order
precedents.cited_holding: The degree of disturbance and its effect upon the life of the community determines whether it is law and order or public order issue

precedents.cited_holding: Public order embraces more of the community than law and order; acts against individuals do not disturb society to the extent of public order breach
